title: Hub24 inflows almost double as big bank platforms fight back
text:
Hub24 managing director Andrew Alcock said the platform will continue to close in on Netwealth and be competitive in picking up business from financial advisers fleeing more restrictive platforms offered by the institutional wealth managers.

“We believe we have a capability that is ahead of the pack,” he told The Australian Financial Review. “Our technology is superior.”

Empire strikes back

Both Netwealth and Hub24 have been beneficiaries of outflows from platforms owned by the big four banks and AMP, largely off the back of shifting sentiment from financial advisers in the wake of the Hayne royal commission.

However, in an attempt to stem the FUA outflows to non-bank platforms, Westpac’s BT Panorama and National Australia Bank’s MLC platforms have recently made competitive moves.

BT surprised the market in July 2018, cutting flat and asset-based fees on its Panorama platform to new lows. MLC in September hired Darren Stevens – a former Mercer and Bravura executive – as group executive, platforms, indicating it may also be ramping up its focus on platform distribution ahead of the slated exit of MLC from NAB.

AMP chief executive Francesco De Ferrari has also listed platform innovation and financial adviser-facing technology as an ongoing focus of his transformation strategy for the troubled wealth manager.

“Institutions are re-pricing and re-developing and announcing changes in strategy,” said Mr Alcock. “We helped lead that innovation and competition, so we welcome it.”

Goldman Sachs analysts list this increasing “competition from incumbent providers” as a downside risk, alongside increasing regulatory scrutiny, but maintain a ‘buy’ recommendation on Hub24 following the September quarterly results.

“Overall we see this as a strong start to the year for Hub and validation of the overall trends towards the speciality platform providers driven by leading investments in functionality and independence from vertical integration,” said analysts Aaron Yeoh and Grace Fulton.

Pole position in managed accounts

While Netwealth tops the charts on a number of key metrics, and the big bank platforms retain market share, Mr Alcock points to Hub24’s dominance in the managed accounts market segment.

Of the $14.4 billion in FUA held by Hub24, 44 per cent is comprised of holdings in managed accounts or portfolios.

Hub24 leads Netwealth in Investment Trends rankings for the managed accounts market, based on both financial adviser sentiment and the research house’s own benchmarks.

Investment Trends wealth management research director Recep III Peker agreed that Hub24’s prime position in the managed accounts segment is significant, given it is the "fastest-growing segment" among financial adviser technology and product recommendation options.

But he said Netwealth is unlikely to be fazed by its second position in the managed accounts market, given its top spot in broader platform rankings.

“It is not a problem for Netwealth,” Mr Peker said. “Hub24 is relatively newer and built its proposition around managed accounts. Netwealth commenced with a focus on direct equities and entered the managed accounts space later.”
description: Hub24 has reported quarterly net inflows of $1.23 billion, as it seeks to maintain a lead over bank-owned wealth management platforms.
